messageBody:
Again, general agreement, except...

So said Lauren Bish on 2/22/2003 --------------------

<snip />
>... if the interface is changing then you
>have a real problem.

If the interface isn't allowed to change, then we have a real problem.
Software changes. Any time change is painful, change is discouraged.
When change is discouraged, we reduce the likelihood of delivering the
right software. My mission is to deliver the right software, so when
the interface isn't allowed to change, I can't do my job.

>Also, as I stated in my posts several times, the independent unit
testers
>were indeed programmers, not QA or testing people - or at least not
solely
>just testing people. They were trained and mentored by people like me
who
>have experience in both disciplines about how to test properly and how
to
>write code properly. Some worked out, some did not, but all learned
from
>it,
>including the people doing the training and mentoring.

So explain to me the difference between what you describe and Pair
Programming combined with TDD. Is it just that other programmers are,
on their own, writing tests for my stuff after I've written it?

>Again, there were two factors involved that greatly improved unit
testing;
>independent eyes creating the tests, and a testing
>mentality/aptitude/attitude. I do believe there is a lot of value in
>independent unit testing.

If you've seen the value, then go with it, to be sure.
